user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarCreate_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarCreate_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 options)
{
    int32                              final_status;
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    final_status = OS_SUCCESS;
    impl         = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    /*
    ** create the underlying mutex
    */
    status = pthread_mutex_init(&impl->mut, NULL);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error: CondVar mutex could not be created. ID = %lu: %s\n",
                 OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(status));
        final_status = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
        ** create the condvar
        */
        status = pthread_cond_init(&impl->cv, NULL);
        if (status != 0)
        {
            pthread_mutex_destroy(&impl->mut);

            OS_DEBUG("Error: CondVar could not be created. ID = %lu: %s\n",
                     OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(status));
            final_status = OS_ERROR;
        }
    }

    return final_status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarCreate_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
static inline unsigned long OS_ObjectIdToInteger(osal_id_t object_id)
{
#ifdef OSAL_OMIT_DEPRECATED
    return object_id.v;
#else
    return object_id;
#endif
}
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragments appear to be statically unreachable. The conditional branches depend on the runtime return values of pthread_mutex_init and pthread_cond_init, so both the error and success branches are potentially reachable. There are no constant conditional expressions, no statements after the return, no unconditional jumps or fall-throughs that would make code unreachable. The OS_DEBUG macro is defined empty, but that simply removes the debug calls at preprocessing rather than leaving unreachable code in the compiled source. The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro and the inline helper functions do not introduce unreachable paths. Therefore no portions of this function need further investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 (unreachable code).
